member.name: T:NPack.SingleComponent
member.summary: A matrix component value modeled by a single-precision floating point.
member.remarks: Use this structure as the type parameter for when you want a matrix of single values, since it implements , which allows numerical operations on value types.

member.remarks: Adapted from an article on lambda-computing.com: http://www.lambda-computing.com/publications/articles/generics/IArithmetic.cs.

member.name: T:NPack.HouseholderReflectionQrDecomposition`2
member.summary: QR decomposition for a rectangular matrix.

remarks.para: For an m-by-n Matrix{T} A with m >= n, the QR decomposition is an m-by-n orthogonal Matrix{T} Q and an n-by-n upper triangular Matrix{T} R so that A = Q * R.

The QR decompostion always exists, even if the Matrix{T} does not have full rank, so the constructor will never fail. The primary use of the QR decomposition is in the least squares solution of non-square systems of simultaneous linear equations. It is well-suited to computation due to the fact that the Q matrix in the decomposition is an orthogonal matrix, allowing errors that arise in its computation to be removed by reforming it to orthogonality.

member.summary: Construct a QR decomposition.

member.summary: Least squares solution of A * X = B.
member.param: Right-hand-side Matrix{T} with as many rows as A and any number of columns.
member.returns: A Matrix{T} that minimized the two norm of Q * R * X - B.
member.exception: Matrix{T} row dimensions must be the same.
Matrix{T} is rank deficient.

member.name: P:NPack.HouseholderReflectionQrDecomposition`2.IsFullRank
member.summary: Gets a value which indicates if the Matrix{T} A is of full rank.
member.value: if R, and hence A, has full rank; otherwise.

member.name: P:NPack.HouseholderReflectionQrDecomposition`2.Q
member.summary: Returns the orthogonal factor Q.

member.name: P:NPack.HouseholderReflectionQrDecomposition`2.R
member.summary: Returns the upper triangular factor R.

member.name: T:NPack.LUDecomposition`2
member.summary: LU decomposition of a rectangular matrix.
member.typeparam: The type of the matrix element.

remarks.para: For an m-by-n Matrix{T} A with m >= n, the LU decomposition is an m-by-n unit lower triangular Matrix{T} L, an n-by-n upper triangular Matrix{T} U, and a permutation vector Pivot of length m so that Pivot * A = L * U. If m < n, then L is m-by-m and U is m-by-n.

The LU decompostion with pivoting always exists, even if the Matrix{T} is singular, so the constructor will never fail. The primary use of the LU decomposition is in the solution of square systems of simultaneous linear equations. There is no solution, or infinite solutions if returns .

member.returns: X so that L * U * X = B.

member.name: M:NPack.MersenneTwister.NextDouble
member.summary: Returns the next pseudo-random value.
member.returns: A pseudo-random double floating point value.

remarks.para: There are two common ways to create a double floating point using MT19937: using and dividing by 0xFFFFFFFF + 1, or else generating two double words and shifting the first by 26 bits and adding the second.

In a newer measurement of the randomness of MT19937 published in the journal "Monte Carlo Methods and Applications, Vol. 12, No. 5-6, pp. 385 393 (2006)" entitled "A Repetition Test for Pseudo-Random Number Generators", it was found that the 32-bit version of generating a double fails at the 95% confidence level when measuring for expected repetitions of a particular number in a sequence of numbers generated by the algorithm.

Due to this, the 53-bit method is implemented here and the 32-bit method of generating a double is not. If, for some reason, the 32-bit method is needed, it can be generated by the following:
(Double)NextUInt32() / ((UInt64)UInt32.MaxValue + 1);

member.returns: If is , this method returns a double-precision pseudo-random number greater than or equal to zero, and less than or equal to one. If is , this method returns a double-precision pseudo-random number greater than or equal to zero and strictly less than one.

member.name: T:NPack.Interfaces.IVectorBuffer`2
member.summary: Defines a vector buffer for storing vector data in a specific format.
member.typeparam: The type of vector to store.
The type of component in the vector.

remarks.para: A vector buffer allows specific storage of vectors in memory. This is useful since modern hardware treats vector data specially, and a specific storage format can take advantage of these capabilities. For example, SSE and SSE2 instructions are found on almost all of the non-embedded, general-purpose CPUs on the market, and these instructions work best when memory is aligned to 16-byte boundaries. Using a Structure of Arrays (SoA) data format is also preferable when performing matrix computations.

member.name: T:NPack.ManagedVectorBuffer`2
member.summary: Defines a vector buffer for storing vector data in a specific format. The stores vectors on the managed heap, and is fully verifiable.
member.typeparam: The type of vector to store.
The type of component in the vector.

remarks.para: A vector buffer allows specific storage of vectors in memory. This is useful since modern hardware treats vector data specially, and a specific storage format can take advantage of these capabilities. For example, SSE and SSE2 instructions are found on almost all of the non-embedded, general-purpose CPUs on the market, and these instructions work best when memory is aligned to 16-byte boundaries. Using a Structure of Arrays (SoA) data format is also preferable when performing matrix computations.
